Trial_Design.evidence: We randomized 18 patients scheduled for a TKA into two groups, A and B.

Intervention.evidence: The first assistant then cut the popliteus tendon in Group A patients but not in Group B patients.

Objective.evidence: The purposes of this study were to (1) evaluate the effect of resecting the popliteus tendon on knee ligament balancing in extension and flexion intraoperatively during posterior stabilized TKA; and (2) evaluate the effect of resecting the popliteus tendon on load distribution on the tibial plateau as determined by an in vitro single limb stance model during TKA.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: We randomized 18 patients scheduled for a TKA into two groups, A and B.

Blinding.evidence: Once component trials were in place, the senior surgeon removed himself from the operating table to allow for a blinded trial.

Number_Randomised.evidence: We randomized 18 patients scheduled for a TKA into two groups, A and B.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The senior surgeon was unable to detect a difference in the knee stability between knees with transected popliteal tendons and those with intact popliteal tendons.
